title: Mr. Johnson's Challenge with Diabetic Foot Ulcer
clinical_history: Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old retired accountant with a 15-year history of Type 2 Diabetes. Over the past 2 months, he has been experiencing a persistent sore on the plantar surface of his right foot. Initially, he noticed some redness and a small bump after a day of unusually long walking. He ignored it, attributing the discomfort to his new pair of shoes. However, when the bump grew into a persistent sore, he sought medical attention. The ulcer is about 2 cm in diameter with evidence of local infection, marked by mild erythema and surrounding edema. Mr. Johnson reports a constant dull ache (P1) at the site of the ulcer, particularly when walking. He denies any recent trauma to the area.

nprs.affected_area: plantar surface of the right foot

aggrevating_factors: Weight-bearing activities such as walking and prolonged standing
picture: [insert image of a diabetic foot ulcer]
easing_factors: Elevating the foot and resting, wearing soft footwear or going barefoot, topical antibiotic ointment
past_history: Long-standing poorly controlled Type 2 Diabetes with occasional episodes of hypoglycemia and history of peripheral neuropathy.
medical_history: Hypertension and hypercholesterolemia managed with medication, obesity.
medications: Metformin 500 mg b.i.d., Lisinopril 10 mg daily, Atorvastatin 20 mg nightly
personal_history: Mr. Johnson is a widower who lives alone. He has two adult children who visit occasionally. Due to his diabetes, he has become less active over the years, contributing to his increased weight. His dietary habits are inconsistent, despite being educated about the importance of managing his condition.
imaging: A recent X-ray of the foot ruled out osteomyelitis, showing no signs of bone involvement.
